Reading through the folding@home web site I see they have been working 
on a client for ATI graphics cards that achieves "a 20x to 40x speed 
increase over comparable CPU code for certain types of calculations in 
FAH". Also Sony have announced a client for the Playstation 3.

More info here (See the high performance FAQ and PS3 FAQ):

http://folding.stanford.edu/faq.html

Now I've often toyed with the idea of building a cluster of very cheap 
PC's as an easy way to get more CPU power. No doubt utilising GPU's 
would require a lot of work but probably is a more attainable option 
than say, utilising an FPGA or some other piece of specialized hardware. 
Hopefully the CPU intensive stuff could be farmed off to a GPU using C 
code or something while the core NEAT algorithm (which typically takes 
up a small percentage of CPU time) could remain in .Net, Java or 
whatever language and environment you are currently using.

While I'm on the subject I've been looking at Intel's new Core 2 Duo 
chips and their performance looks good. Sisoft Sandra reports an FPU 
score of 15,406M Whetstones for the E6600, which compares to 7,477M for 
the Athlon X2 3800+ and 3,482M for a single core Athlon XP 3200+ (I 
currently own an overclocled 2400+).

So for me right now I can potentially get a 5x speed increase just by 
upgrading my PC (and multi-threading SharpNEAT). Also the Core 2 Duo has 
power consumption of just 65W (75W for the very top end chip). Although 
you can theoretically get a 35W Athlon X2 3800+, but I've yet to find 
anyone who actually sells them.

Colin.
